Award.AwardTitle: NSF INCLUDES DDLP: Southeastern Compact for Inclusive Student Transitions in Engineering and Physical Sciences (SCI-STEPS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Physical science and engineering remain the least diverse of all STEM fields---with regard to women, underrepresented minorities, and persons with disabilities---across all levels of STEM education and training. SCI-STEPS is an NSF INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Pilot that will address this persistent challenge by developing a complete end-to-end pipeline (or system of pathways) from the beginning of college to the PhD, and then into the workforce. Many isolated efforts to broaden participation have shown promise, but they have not produced big enough impact. SCI-STEPS represents a concerted set of coordinated interventions---consciously facilitated, systemically linked, and purposefully disseminated. SCI-STEPS represents a broad regional network among major research universities, Historically Black Colleges and Universities, comprehensive universities, community colleges, national labs, and major scientific organizations. The goal of the network is to ensure that underrepresented individuals in the physical sciences and engineering can get from their starting point in STEM higher education---freshmen at 2-year or 4-year college---through the higher education pathways leading to an appropriate terminal degree and employment in the STEM workforce.

Women, underrepresented minorities, and persons with disabilities collectively represent the majority of college-age individuals entering higher education with an expressed interest in physical science and engineering. A growing body of research indicates that academic and social integration may be even more influential than academic abilities for retention of students. Thus, interventions aimed at stemming the losses of these individuals must ultimately be aimed at changing the system---including unwelcoming institutional climates, racial/ethnic/gender stereotyping, a lack of mentors with whom to identify, and evaluation methods that emphasize conformity over individual capabilities---rather than changing the individual. The SCI-STEPS pilot focuses effort on institutional readiness for implementation of best practice interventions at four key junctures: (i) college freshman to sophomore; (ii) undergraduate to graduate; (iii) PhD to postdoc; and (iv) postdoc to workforce.The pilot will proceed in three steps: (1) a planning phase, (2) development of an initial end-to-end pathways model with four Juncture Transition teams, and (3) scale-up of the SCI-STEPS "network of networks" with all initial partners. By addressing these objectives through a collective impact framework and embedded research, this pilot will demonstrate how best-practice interventions at each pathway juncture can be dovetailed and scaled up across a broad range of institutional types and across a large but distinct geographical area. Addressing these objectives will thus also serve to advance Broadening Participation efforts at a national scale, by suggesting the forms of institutional partnerships and best-practices that may inform other alliances in other STEM disciplines and/or different regional areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Physical science and engineering (P&E) remain the least diverse of all STEM fields---with regards to women, underrepresented minorities, and persons with disabilities---across all levels of STEM education and training. SCI-STEPS was a pilot INCLUDES Alliance that sought to address this persistent challenge by developing a complete end-to-end “pipeline” (or system of pathways) from the beginning of college to the PhD, and then into the workforce (teaching, research in government laboratories, R&D in industry). Many isolated efforts to broaden participation have shown promise, but they have not produced big enough impact. SCI-STEPS represents a concerted set of coordinated interventions---consciously facilitated, systemically linked, and purposefully disseminated. SCI-STEPS represents a broad regional alliance among major research universities, Historically Black Colleges and Universities, comprehensive universities, community colleges, national labs, and major scientific organizations. The goal of our compact (we use “compact” in the sense of covenant or mutual commitment) was to ensure that underrepresented individuals (women, minorities, and persons with physical, developmental, or learning disabilities) in the physical sciences and engineering can get from their starting point in STEM higher education---freshmen at 2-year or 4-year college---through the higher education pathways leading to an appropriate terminal degree, and then employment in the STEM workforce.

SCI-STEPS brought together a broad coalition spanning the Southeast, representing a regional scale effort that would be the basis for a national scale INCLUDES Alliance, where partners working to advance students in P&E are connected in an end-to-end pathways model. Our collaborative strategy was to use the Collective Impacts framework to bring all the partners together to design and implement a project infrastructure with shared goals and metrics. The Backbone consisted of a central administrator to facilitate collaboration, to convene partners in Collective Impact teamwork, to keep communication open to all partners, and to disseminate information, such as best practices used and project resources. The Pilot included research on the dissemination and scale-up strategies used, and the methods by which the collaboration grew its interconnectivity, starting from pairwise institutional matchups up to state- and region-wide “networks of networks”. 

Products and Dissemination: We focused our Pilot on four juncture transitions in the STEM higher-education pathways: (1) community college to 4-year college/university, (2) undergraduate to graduate (including freshman retention), (3) graduate to postdoc, and (4) postdoc to STEM professional (academia, national lab, industry). We developed intentional interconnectivity among our partners to enable students to flow seamlessly through these four junctures. Examples of products from the four JT Innovation Hubs are as follows. 

JT Innovation Hub 1: Northern Virginia Community College (NOVA) and George Mason University (GMU) designed a series of recruitment events to support students to make this transition. Discussions among faculty at both institutions led to transfer events at GMU and then to transfer events held at NOVA, and new STEM Bridge events for students. The team produced documentation, incorporating feedback from students and alumni, to enable other 2-year/4-year institutional pairs to replicate their success, thus enabling broad expansion and scaleup of the model.

JT Innovation Hub 2: Retention of undergraduates through research immersion was the main focus, looking in particular at how research experience starting in the freshman year would increase retention in the major and into graduate school. The Pilot provided seed funding for undergraduates to conduct research at a partner institution during the summer, and the project is preparing partners in JT Innovation Hub 3 to receive graduates from these institutions.

JT Innovation Hub 3: The team looked at two innovations: increasing ease of access to graduate students for postdoc positions by centralizing information about all available opportunities, and the model of a career workshop, in which participants learn to create a strong CV, participate in mock interviews to learn interview etiquette with situational role play. The workshop also incorporated hiring agents from national labs to give overview of the labs and situational examples of the interview process. The framework was developed to then be replicated at other partner institutions using mostly partners’ campus resources. By the end of the very first career workshop, one participant was hired by a national lab.

JT Innovation Hub 4: The team designed a novel “round robin” approach to connecting the various “future faculty postdoctoral fellowship” opportunities at their campuses. The “round robin” consisted of postdocs from partner institutions being invited to give a seminar talk as an “Emerging Scholar” in a department that has interest in hiring for a faculty position. The visit is planned as if it were a mock interview, including individual meetings with faculty, department chairs, and deans. Feedback is given to help the postdoc improve their skill. These postdocs then become prime recruits for faculty hiring soon thereafter.

All four JT Innovation Hubs benefitted from trainings in Holistic Evaluation and Admissions, in collaboration with the IGEN INCLUDES Alliance, and in Mentoring, in collaboration with the NRMN Network.
